    Sameer Kulkarni

    Optimization Enthusiast, Engineer@Google Deep Mind, Ph.D. in Computer Science by Education

    • Pasadena, CA

    Publications

    ---
    You can also find my articles on my Google Scholar profile.

    Books

    Improving compiler optimizations using machine learning

    Published in PhD Thesis, University of Delaware, 2014

    This work demonstrates that machine learning models can successfully predict effective sequences of compiler optimizations, outperforming default compiler settings.

    Recommended citation: Kulkarni, S. (2014). "Improving compiler optimizations using machine learning." PhD Thesis, University of Delaware.
    Download Paper

    Journal Articles

    A transactional memory with automatic performance tuning

    Published in ACM Transactions on Architecture and Code Optimization (TACO), 2012

    By leveraging both static analysis and a low-overhead dynamic profiling framework, the system can select the most appropriate TM algorithm to adapt to workload changes and achieve better performance than any single, statically configured STM.

    Recommended citation: Wang, Q., Kulkarni, S., Cavazos, J., & Spear, M. (2012). "A transactional memory with automatic performance tuning." ACM Transactions on Architecture and Code Optimization (TACO), 8(4), 1-23.
    Download Paper

    Conference Papers

    Automatic construction of inlining heuristics using machine learning

    Published in 2013 IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO), 2013

    This work shows that the generated heuristics outperform expertly-tuned, manual heuristics in the HotSpot Java Virtual Machine by learning from a diverse set of static code features, achieving speedups of up to 89%.

    Recommended citation: Kulkarni, S., Cavazos, J., Wimmer, C., & Simon, D. (2013). "Automatic construction of inlining heuristics using machine learning." In Proceedings of the 2013 IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO) (pp. 1-12).
    Download Paper

    Mitigating the compiler optimization phase-ordering problem using machine learning

    Published in ACM SIGPLAN Notices (OOPSLA), 2012

    By formulating the phase-ordering problem as a Markov process and using neuro-evolution to build a predictive model, this technique achieves significant speedups over the well-engineered fixed optimization order in Jikes RVM.

    Recommended citation: Kulkarni, S., & Cavazos, J. (2012). "Mitigating the compiler optimization phase-ordering problem using machine learning." ACM SIGPLAN Notices, 47(10), 147-162.
    Download Paper

    Towards applying machine learning to adaptive transactional memory

    Published in Proceedings of the 6th ACM SIGPLAN Workshop on Transactional Computing, 2011

    This preliminary work shows that a model can effectively learn to choose the best TM algorithm for a given workload by using dynamic profiling to gather program characteristics, providing a baseline for future research into adaptive TM mechanisms.

    Recommended citation: Wang, Q., Kulkarni, S., Cavazos, J. V., & Spear, M. (2011). "Towards applying machine learning to adaptive transactional memory." In Proceedings of the 6th ACM SIGPLAN workshop on Transactional computing (pp. 8-32).
    Download Paper

    An evaluation of different modeling techniques for iterative compilation

    Published in 2011 International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO), 2011

    This work introduces a novel "tournament predictor" that outperforms state-of-the-art predictors by framing the problem as a pairwise comparison of optimization sequences, achieving an average of 75% improvement over the Open64 compiler’s most aggressive setting.

    Recommended citation: Park, E., Kulkarni, S., & Cavazos, J. (2011). "An evaluation of different modeling techniques for iterative compilation." In 2011 International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (pp. 91-100). IEEE.
    Download Paper

    Redefining connectivity: Unifying mobile communication with the internet

    Published in 2006 3rd IEEE Consumer Communications and Networking Conference (CCNC), 2006

    The system aims to provide real-time, ‘always-on’ communication and unifies mobile and desktop users.

    Recommended citation: Kulkarni, S. S., & Ali, S. L. (2006). "Redefining connectivity: Unifying mobile communication with the internet." In 2006 3rd IEEE Consumer Communications and Networking Conference (Vol. 1, pp. 297-301). IEEE.
    Download Paper

    Device independent mobile application controller for remote administration of a server over a GPRS link using a J2ME cellular

    Published in First India Annual Conference, 2004. Proceedings of the IEEE INDICON, 2004

    The application allows a user to control any desktop computer or server by sending commands via an HTTP connection from a J2ME-enabled cell phone, offering a flexible solution for system management.

    Recommended citation: Kulkarni, S., Diwan, S., & Bansode, N. K. (2004). "Device independent mobile application controller for remote administration of a server over a GPRS link using a J2ME cellular." In First India Annual Conference, 2004. Proceedings of the IEEE INDICON (pp. 37-41). IEEE.
    Download Paper
